revision.comment: /* Plot summary */
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = The Boss | image = The Boss poster.png | alt = A woman sitting on a chair with two dogs | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Ben Falcone]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Ben Falcone * [[Melissa McCarthy]] * [[Will Ferrell]] * [[Adam McKay]] * [[Chris Henchy]] }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Ben Falcone * Melissa McCarthy * Steve Mallory }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * Melissa McCarthy * [[Kristen Bell]] * [[Kathy Bates]] * [[Tyler Labine]] * [[Peter Dinklage]] }}<!--DO NOT CHANGE PER POSTER BILLING BLOCK--> | music = [[Christopher Lennertz]] | cinematography = [[Julio Macat]] | editing = [[Craig Alpert]] | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Gary Sanchez Productions]] * [[On the Day Productions]] }} | distributor = [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2016|03|21|[[Sydney]]|2016|04|08|United States|}} | runtime = 99 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 98:51--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/boss-film-1 | title=''THE BOSS'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=May 17, 2016 | accessdate=May 24, 2016}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $29 million<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/2016/film/box-office/box-office-melissa-mccarthy-batman-v-superman-1201746025/|title=Box Office: Melissa McCarthy Looks to Unseat ‘Batman v Superman’|date=April 4, 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=April 5, 2016}}</ref> | gross = $78.8 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=michelledarnell.htm |title=The Boss (2016) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref> }} '''''The Boss''''' is a 2016 American [[comedy film]] directed by [[Ben Falcone]] and written by Falcone, [[Melissa McCarthy]] and Steve Mallory. The film stars McCarthy, [[Kristen Bell]], [[Ella Anderson]], [[Tyler Labine]], [[Kathy Bates]], [[Annie Mumolo]], [[Timothy Simons]], and [[Peter Dinklage]]. The film follows a wealthy woman who, after being arrested and losing her fortune, uses her assistant's daughter's Dandelion Girls cookie sales to return to the top. The film was released on April 8, 2016, by [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]], received generally negative reviews from critics and grossed $78 million worldwide.
==Plot summary== The story follows Michelle Darnell, a titan of industry who is sent to prison for [[insider trading]], denounced by her former lover, Renault, who still holds a heavy grudge towards her for their breakup, after getting a promotion a few years ago. After doing her time, Michelle emerges, ready to rebrand herself as America's latest sweetheart, but not everyone she steamrolled is not so quick to forgive and forget. With nowhere to go and no one to scam, Michelle is forced to move in with former assistant Claire and her young daughter, Rachel. Now at her lowest point, Michelle wastes no time in devising a winner-take-all plan to rebuild her empire.
==Cast== * [[Melissa McCarthy]] as Michelle Darnell, a rich and powerful businesswoman, who was abandoned by several different families for an unknown reason, which caused her to have a bitter personality against the idea of having a family. She is arrested by the FBI for insider trading, serves time, and is on parole throughout the film until the end. ** Chandler Head as 5-year-old Michelle ** Vivian Falcone (Melissa McCarthy's real-life daughter) as 10-year-old Michelle ** [[Isabella Amara]] as 15-year-old Michelle * [[Kristen Bell]] as Claire Rawlings, Rachel’s mother and Michelle's personal assistant and single mom, who at first stops working for her, after Michelle's arrest. She creates an empire along with Michelle, by selling homemade brownies Claire bakes. * [[Peter Dinklage]] as Ronald/Renault, an unscrupulous business man and rival to Michelle. He holds a long time grudge towards Michelle due to the fact that they dated in the past, but broke up due to a promotion Michelle got, which instantly changed her behavior and caused them to break up. He was also responsible for turning Michelle over to the authorities for insider trading. He constantly names himself Renault and follows the lifestyle of a samurai. * [[Ella Anderson]] as Rachel Rawlings, Claire's 10-year-old daughter, who was part of a girl scout team called the Dandelions, but quits after being bullied and chastised by Helen and being convinced to join alongside Michelle in her scheme. * [[Tyler Labine]] as Mike Beals, a co-worker of Claire's, who seems to try to woo Claire, who constantly rejects him softly. * [[Kathy Bates]] as Ida Marquette, a former mentor of Michelle's who is the owner of a glue factory. She cut off their alliance, after Michelle decided to push Ida away from a deal she made from another company. * [[Timothy Simons]] as Stephan, Ron's gay personal assistant. * [[Annie Mumolo]] as Helen Kreagan, an arrogant, cunning and narcissistic woman and mother to one of the Dandelions, who takes pride in verbally abusing the other girls. She thinks she's better than everyone else and always compliments herself, even going as far to call herself successful when she isn't. * [[Kristen Schaal]] as Sandy, the leader of the Dandelions, who is pompously berated by Helen. * [[Cecily Strong]] as Dana Dandridge, Claire's vain, selfish, sarcastic and overbearing boss, who describes Michelle as one of her "two personal heroes", with the second being [[Benedict Cumberbatch]]. * [[Cedric Yarbrough]] as Tito, Michelle's former bodyguard, who constantly cheers along with Michelle. * Mary Sohn as Jan Keller, a mother to one of the Dandelions. * Eva Peterson as Chrystal Delvechio, one of the Darnell's Darlings, with a violent behavior. * Presley Coley as Hannah Kreagan, one of the Dandelions and Helen's daughter, who is manipulated by her mother. * Aleandra Newcomb as Mariana Gutierrez, one of the Darnell's Darlings. * [[Ben Falcone]] as Marty, Michelle's former lawyer. * [[Margo Martindale]] as Sister Agnes Aluminata, the mother superior of the children's home where Michelle lived. * [[Michael McDonald (comedian)|Michael McDonald]] as Bryce Crean, one of the "friends" of Michelle's past. * Steve Mallory as Carl, one of the "friends" of Michelle's past. * Larry Dorf as Guard Kenny * Damon Jones as Waiter * [[T-Pain]] as himself * [[Gayle King]] as herself * [[Mitch Silpa]] as Guard Clemmons (Deleted Scenes) * Jim Cashman as Guard John (Deleted Scenes) * [[Carrot Top]] as a centaur version of himself in a dream that Michelle had. (Deleted Scenes) * [[Dax Shepard]] as Kyle Marquette, Ida's "son". (Unrated Cut) * [[Dave Bautista]] as Chad, the leader of the Falcon Rangers. (Uncredited/Alternate Ending)
==Production== Initially announced as ''Michelle Darnell'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/melissa-mccarthy-michelle-darnell-april-2016-release-clifford-the-big-red-dog-universal-1201341553/ |title=Melissa McCarthy’s ‘Michelle Darnell’ Gets New Title – Update |publisher=Deadline.com |date=September 15, 2015 |accessdate=September 15, 2015 }}</ref> the film is based on a character McCarthy created for the comedy troupe [[Groundlings]].<ref name=McCarthy>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/melissa-mccarthy-ben-falcone-5-new-projects-1201245084/|title=Melissa McCarthy and Ben Falcone Preview 5 New Film Projects - Variety|work=Variety|accessdate=March 27, 2015}}</ref> Universal was at first unable to decide on the gender of the film's antagonist. Before [[Peter Dinklage]] was finally cast, the studio also considered [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[Jon Hamm]] and [[Sandra Bullock]] as possibilities.<ref name=Dinklage>{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Peter Dinklage to Star with Melissa McCarthy in ‘Michelle Darnell’ (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/peter-dinklake-michelle-darnell-casting-melissa-mccarthy-1201407638/|accessdate=March 27, 2015|publisher=variety.com|date=February 4, 2015}}</ref> [[Kathy Bates]] plays Ida Marquette, Darnell's mentor,<ref name=Bates>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Kathy Bates Reuniting With Melissa McCarthy for 'Michelle Darnell' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kathy-bates-reuniting-melissa-mccarthy-772782|accessdate=March 27, 2015|publisher=hollywoodreporter.com|date=February 12, 2015}}</ref> and [[Kristen Bell]] plays Claire, Darnell's former personal assistant.<ref name=Bell>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Kristen Bell Joins Melissa McCarthy in 'Michelle Darnell'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kristen-bell-joins-melissa-mccarthy-774089|accessdate=March 27, 2015|publisher=hollywoodreporter.com|date=February 18, 2015}}</ref>
===Filming=== Set in Chicago, the movie began filming in Chicago on March 12, 2015. In addition to filming in Chicago, the movie was also filmed throughout various locations in the Atlanta, Georgia area, including [[Agnes Scott College]], Crescent Avenue in [[Midtown Atlanta|Midtown]], Glenwood Park, and the Buckhead Loop area.<ref>{{cite news|date=May 3, 2015|title=Melissa McCarthy’s sassy new red hairdo|url=http://buzz.blog.ajc.com/2015/05/03/melissa-mccarthys-sassy-new-red-hairdo/|accessdate=May 6, 2015}}</ref>
==Release== The first official full-length trailer was released on November 19, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=See the first trailer for Melissa McCarthy's ''The Boss''|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/11/19/the-boss-trailer-melissa-mccarthy|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=November 21, 2015|date=November 19, 2015}}</ref> The film was released on April 8, 2016.<ref name=release>{{cite news|title=Melissa McCarthy Comedy 'Michelle Darnell' Gets Release Date|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/melissa-mccarthy-comedy-michelle-darnell-761230|accessdate=March 27, 2015|date=January 5, 2015}}</ref>
===Box office=== ''The Boss'' grossed $63.3 million in the United States and Canada, plus $15.5 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $78.8 million against a budget of $29 million.<ref name=BOM />
In the United States and Canada, pre-release tracking suggested the film would gross $20–24 million from 3,480 theaters in its opening weekend, besting fellow newcomers ''[[Hardcore Henry]]'' ($7–10 million projection) and ''[[Demolition (2015 film)|Demolition]]'' ($2–3 million projection).<ref name="preview">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/the-boss-hardcore-henry-demoition-batman-v-superman-box-office-preview-1201732456/ |title= Melissa McCarthy Will Try To ‘Boss’ Around ‘BvS’ At Box Office; Will ‘Hardcore Henry’ Sway Audiences? — Preview |work= deadline.com}}</ref> The film grossed $985,000 from its early Thursday screenings and $8.1 million on its first day. It went on to gross $23.6 million in its opening weekend, finishing first at the box office.<ref name="Thursday">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/the-weekend-box-office-batman-v-superman-melissa-mccarthy-1201734178/ |title=‘Batman V. Superman’ Likely To Cross $300M Early Next Week; ‘The Boss’ Cashing In $21M Paycheck – B.O. Update |work= deadline.com}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Critical response=== ''The Boss'' received generally negative reviews from critics. Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film an approval rating of 22%, based on 182 reviews, with an average of 4.4/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Melissa McCarthy remains as fiercely talented as ever, but her efforts aren't enough to prop up the baggy mess of inconsistent gags and tissue-thin writing that brings down ''The Boss''."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_boss_2016/ | title=The Boss (2016) | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher=[[Fandango Media]] | accessdate=March 7, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 40 out of 100, based on reviews from 39 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-boss | title=The Boss Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=March 7, 2018}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "C+" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="Thursday"/>
=== Accolades === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Recipient ! Result |- | [[Alliance of Women Film Journalists]] | Actress Most in Need of a New Agent | rowspan="3"| [[Melissa McCarthy]] | {{nom}} |- | [[2016 Teen Choice Awards|Teen Choice Awards]] | [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Actress – Comedy|Choice Movie Actress: Comedy]] | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[43rd People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Awards]] | rowspan="2"| Favorite Comedic Movie Actress | {{won}} |- | [[Kristen Bell]] | {{nom}} |- |}
==References== {{Reflist|40em}}

{{Ben Falcone}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The Peter Pyramid''''' ( {{ISBN|0-04-440057-8}} ) is a book published in 1986 by Dr. [[Laurence Peter|Laurence J. Peter]], who also wrote ''[[Peter Principle|The Peter Principle]]'' published in 1969.
In this book he turns his attention to proliferating [[bureaucracy|bureaucracies]], burgeoning officialdom and does for the system what the [[Peter Principle]] did for the individual.
With a host of unfortunate examples for real life, Dr. Peter shows how major organizations are constructed upside down, with the point of operation all but invisible beneath the bulk of a top-heavy administration.
Cutting through the red tape he suggests, with humour and wisdom, dozens of ways to simplify meaningless complexity and stop the current procession of the bland leading the bland.
==Contents== # Pyramid Power # Peter Pyramid # Proliferating Pathology # Progressive Processes # Pyramid Proficiency
{{DEFAULTSORT:Peter Pyramid}} {{econ-book-stub}} [[Category:1986 books]] [[Category:Business books]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Venture Café | logo = | type = [[Nonprofit company|Nonprofit]] | founded = {{start date and age|2009}} | founders = [[Tim Rowe]] | hq_location = [[Boston]] | hq_location_city = [[Massachusetts]] | hq_location_country = U.S. | areas_served = 8 cities | key_people = [[Tim Rowe]] | industry = [[Technology]], [[Startups]] | products = Workspace for startups, small businesses, [[freelancers]] and [[entrepreneurs]] | brands = Venture Café, Venture Café Global, [[Innovation Hall]], [[District Hall]] | subsid = | services = [[Coworking|Shared workspaces]] and related services for entrepreneurs | owners = | num_locations = | num_locations_year = | num_employees = }}
'''Venture Café''' is a nonprofit hosting community-focused events and programs which support early-stage entrepreneurs.
There are currently eight Venture Cafés in cities across the Midwest, South, and Northeastern regions of the United States, and in Tokyo, Japan, and Rotterdam, The Netherlands. Each Venture Café is independently managed and runs the flagship program, the Thursday Gathering. Recently, Venture Café Providence recently was announced through a partnership with the city of Providence.<ref name="wpri-vencaf">{{cite web| url=https://www.wpri.com/news/local-news/providence/mayor-elorza-nonprofit-leaders-launch-innovation-partnership/1432204478 | first=Dan | last=McGowan | date=10 September 2018 | accessdate=5 October 2018 | title=Mayor Elorza, nonprofit leaders launch innovation partnership }}</ref>
== Venture Café Boston ==
The Venture Café was originally conceived as a restaurant located in the CIC in Boston, Massachusetts.<ref name="bostonglobe-hottest">{{cite web |title=How a failed restaurant became Cambridge’s hottest Thursday spot|work=Boston Globe |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2018/06/21/this-could-hottest-place-town-thursday-night-and-beer-free/so61lJpjP7HcZLXTCEGvcK/story.html|first=Scott|last=Kirsner|date= 21 June 2018|accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref> The restaurant failed to attract investment and was reimagined as a gathering for the entrepreneurial community based on the book Venture Café by Teresa Esser.<ref name="venture-name">{{cite web |title=Venture Café’s mission is connecting innovators to make things happen.|work=Venture Cafe Official Website |url=http://venturecafeglobal.org/about/|date= 24 August 2018 |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref> Venture Café Kendall launched in 2009 bringing together hundreds of entrepreneurs each week for the flagship program, the Thursday Gathering.
== Venture Café St. Louis ==
In 2014, Venture Café expanded to the [[Cortex Innovation Community]] in [[St. Louis]], Missouri, to bring together the emerging startup community.<ref name="stltoday-cambridge">{{cite web |title=Cambridge Innovation Center opens at Cortex|work=St. Louis Post Dispatch |url=https://www.stltoday.com/business/columns/building-blocks/cambridge-innovation-center-opens-at-cortex/article_202c0df4-dbbb-567e-aec8-32ee0a9eff35.html|first=Tim|last=Bryant|date= Sep 29, 2014 |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref> The success of the St. Louis location prompted the launch of Venture Cafés in other cities and ultimately the creation of Venture Café Global Institute, a public benefit corporation based in both St. Louis and Boston.<ref name="silicon-venture">{{cite web |title=T-REX and Venture Cafe STL are changing St. Louis’ startup landscape|work=Silicon Prairie News |url=http://siliconprairienews.com/2018/03/t-rex-venture-cafe-changing-st-louis-startup-landscape/|first=Christine|last=McGuigan|date=2 March 2018 |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2014, the City of Boston and Venture Café Kendall opened District Hall, a free drop-in workspace for entrepreneurs, including an event venue, restaurant and coffee shop. In 2018, as part of St. Louis Cortex District's new 4220 Duncan building anchored by Microsoft, Venture Cafe launches Innovation Hall in St. Louis based upon Boston's District Hall.<ref name="nextstl-innovationhall">{{cite web |title=Cortex Unveils New 4220 Duncan Building|work=NextSTL |url=https://nextstl.com/2018/05/cortex-unveils-new-4220-duncan-building/|first=Jason |last=Deem |date=10 May 2018 |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref> The St. Louis location will also be the first to launch the Education Hub, also known as EdHub STL, a program supporting and bringing together innovators in education to benefit youth access to education.<ref>{{cite web|title=Venture Cafe St. Louis To Open Innovation Hall At Cortex|url=http://eqstl.com/venture-cafe-st-louis-open-innovation-hall-cortex/|date=12 April 2018}}</ref> EdHub STL is inspired by the Forward Through Ferguson report which calls for an innovation education hub to address the region's most entrenched educational issues.<ref name="fwdthruferguson">{{cite web |title=Create an Innovative Education Hub|work=Forward Through Ferguson |url=https://forwardthroughferguson.org/calls-to-action/innovative-education-hub/|date= 24 August 2018 |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref>
== Programs == === Thursday Gathering === The flagship program of Venture Café, is the Thursday Gathering, a weekly, community-focused event that provides opportunities for new and experienced entrepreneurs the ability to exchange ideas and support. The Thursday Gathering includes several free educational sessions aimed at entrepreneurs to learn how to start and run a business. The Gatherings are intentionally informal allowing for more opportunity to engage in creative and speculative ideas and look for collaborators, co-founders, mentors, or investors.<ref name="venture-name" />
=== Civic Innovation Centers === Venture Cafés in St. Louis, Boston, and Philadelphia currently offer free drop-in workspace for entrepreneurs to work and collaborate in addition to paid event and meeting rooms and restaurants and coffeeshops.
=== Education === Venture Café Foundation in Boston currently runs the Roxbury Innovation Center and St. Louis is launching EdHub STL in 2018.<ref name="bizjournal-cortex">{{cite web |title='Innovation center,' restaurant to open at Cortex|work=St. Louis Business Journal |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2018/04/11/innovation-center-restaurant-to-open-at-cortex.html|date= 11 April 2018 |accessdate=24 August 2018| first=Steph |last=Kukuljan}}</ref> Both programs focus on bringing together innovators in education including students, parents, administration, and teachers to help solve inequities in education and introduce youth to entrepreneurship and STEAM activities.
=== Café Nights === Café Nights are monthly or quarterly versions of the Thursday Gathering located outside the weekly event.
== See also ==
* [[Co-working]]
== External links ==
* [http://vencaf.org/ Venture Café Foundation Official Website] * [http://vencaf.org/venture-cafe-st-louis/ Venture Café St. Louis Official Website]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Victoria B. Mars | image = Victoria Mars at the 27th session of the Foreign Investment Advisory Council in Russia.jpg | image_size = Victoria Mars at the Foreign Investment Advisory Council in Russia in 2013 | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = [[Foxcroft School]] | alma mater = [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]]
[[Yale University]] | employer = | occupation = Businesswoman, philanthropist | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = [[Forrest Mars, Jr.]]
Virginia Cretella | relatives = siblings: [[Marijke Mars]], [[Pamela Mars-Wright]] and [[Valerie Mars]] }} '''Victoria B. Mars''' is an American heiress, businesswoman and billionaire. She previously served as the chairman of [[Mars, Incorporated]]. ==Early life== Victoria B. Mars is a fourth generation member of the [[Mars family]].{{cite web|url=http://www.greatplacetowork.com/2014-conference-speakers/2344-victoria-mars|title=Events Page|first=|last=Great Place to Work|website=Great Place To Work United States|accessdate=8 August 2018}} She is the daughter of [[Forrest Mars, Jr.]] and Virginia Cretella. She has three sisters: [[Marijke Mars]], Pamela Mars-Wright and [[Valerie Mars]].{{cite web|title= Forrest E. Mars Jr., enigmatic steward of family confectionery, dies at 84 |publisher= washingtonpost.com |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/forrest-e-mars-jr-enigmatic-steward-of-family-confectionery-dies-at-84/2016/07/27/0265c442-5400-11e6-b7de-dfe509430c39_story.html | author= Emily Langer| date= 2016-07-27 |accessdate=2018-04-06}} Her paternal great-grandfather, [[Franklin Clarence Mars]], founded Mars, Incorporated in 1911.David A. Kaplan, [http://fortune.com/2013/01/17/mars-incorporated-a-pretty-sweet-place-to-work/ Mars Incorporated: A pretty sweet place to work], ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', January 17, 2013 Her paternal great-grandmother, [[Ethel V. Mars]], was a horsebreeder at [[Milky Way Farm]] in [[Giles County, Tennessee]]. She was educated at [[Foxcroft School]] in [[Middleburg, Virginia]], from which she graduated in 1974.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxcroft.org/discover/at_a_glance|title=At a Glance - Foxcroft School - Middleburg, VA|website=www.foxcroft.org|accessdate=8 August 2018}} She graduated from [[Yale University]]. She earned an MBA in Finance from the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School of Business]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1984.Matthew Brodsky, [http://whartonmagazine.com/issues/winter-2015/hungry-for-a-sweeter-workplace/ Hungry for a Sweeter Workplace?], ''Wharton Magazine'', Winter 2015 ==Career== She started her career working for Mars, Incorporated in [[Haguenau]], [[France]] in 1978, where she served as Assistant Brand Manager for [[Milky Way (chocolate bar)|Milky Way]], followed by Export Manager. In 1984, she served as Director of the Marine Systems Division of Mars Electronics International. Two years later, in 1986, she was appointed Vice President of S&F, Commercial, and People and Organization for [[Dove (chocolate)|Dove]] of [[Burr Ridge, Illinois]] in suburban [[Chicago]]. A decade later, in 1997, she was appointed Ombudsman at Mars, Incorporated. She was still serving in that position in 2013. She has served on the board of directors of Mars, Incorporated since 2006. Eight years later, in April 2014, she was appointed as its chairman, replacing [[Stephen M. Badger]].[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/new-chairman-of-mars-incorporated-victoria-b-mars-delivers-keynote-at-2014-great-place-to-work-conference-2014-04-04 New Chairman Of Mars, Incorporated, Victoria B. Mars Delivers Keynote At 2014 Great Place to Work® Conference], ''[[MarketWatch]]'', April 4, 2014{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=261653469&privcapId=184468&previousCapId=21766682&previousTitle=Tokai+Pharmaceuticals,+Inc.|title=Mars, Incorporated: CEO and Executives - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|accessdate=8 August 2018}} She was a keynote speaker at the 2014 annual conference organized by Great Place to Work, a non-profit organization which promotes employee well-being. In February 2015, she attended a meeting chaired by [[Annick Girardin]], the French Minister of State for Development and Francophony, alongside [[Franck Riboud]], the chairman of [[Danone]], to launch the [[Livelihoods Funds]], which promotes [[sustainable development]] in agribusiness on the African continent.[http://basedoc.diplomatie.gouv.fr/vues/Kiosque/FranceDiplomatie/kiosque.php?fichier=bafr2015-02-05.html Déclarations officielles de politique étrangère du 05 février 2015] She inherited about 8 percent stake of Mars Inc. in 2016, which made her a [[billionaire]]. According to [[Forbes]], her shares were valued worth of 5.9 billion USD (March 2018).{{cite web|title= The World's Billionaires: 296. Victoria Mars |publisher= Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/victoria-mars/?list=billionaires|year=2018|accessdate=2018-04-06}} ==Charity work== She serves as the secretary of the board of trustees of her alma mater, [[Foxcroft School]]. She serves on the board of [http://largelandscapes.org/ The Center for Large Landscape Conservation] in [[Bozeman, Montana]].{{cite web|url=http://largelandscapes.org/people/|title=Staff, Consultants and Board Members - Center for Large Landscape Conservation|website=largelandscapes.org|accessdate=8 August 2018}} She made charitable contributions to the [[Charles Darwin Foundation]] in 2003 and 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/CDF-Annual-2003f.pdf|title=Charles Darwin Foundation, Inc.: 2003 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/CDF2004.pdf|title=Charles Darwin Foundation, Inc.: 2004 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} She also donated to the [[Galapagos Conservancy]] in 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/FINAL-annual-report-2007.pdf|title=Galapagos Institute: 2007 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} 2008,{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/GCAnnualReport2008small.pdf|title=Galapagos Conservancy: 2008 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} 2009,{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/GC-Annual-Report-2009-FINAL.pdf|title=Galapagos Conservancy: 2009 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} 2010,{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/GCAnnualReport2010smaller.pdf|title=Galapagos Conservancy: 2010 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} 2011,{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/GCAnnualReport2011-12-RVSDsmall2.pdf|title=Galapagos Conservancy: 2011 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} 2012,{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/GCAnnualReport-FY13-bookletweb.pdf|title=Galapagos Conservancy: 2012 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} and 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.galapagos.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/GCAnnualReport-FY2014_web.pdf|title=Galapagos Conservancy: 2013 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} She made donations to the [[Mystic Seaport]], a maritime museum in [[Mystic, Connecticut]], in 2011-2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.mysticseaport.org/wp-content/uploads/2011-2012.pdf|title=Mystic Seaport: 2011-2012 Annual Financial Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} Additionally, she donated to the [[High Mountain Institute]], a non-profit organization headquartered in [[Leadville, Colorado]] which teaches young people about the environment, in 2012 and 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.hminet.org/sites/hminet.org/files/hmi_annual_report_2012_final_lores.pdf|title=High Mountain Institute: 2012 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hminet.org/sites/hminet.org/files/annual_report_fye_2013_1.pdf|title=High Mountain Institute: 2013 Annual Report|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} She was a donor to the [[Thorncroft Equestrian Center]] in [[Malvern, Pennsylvania]] in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://thorncroft.org/2014pdf/ThorncroftNews_Fall2014.pdf|title=Thorncroft Equestrian Center: Fall 2014|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2018}} ==Personal life== She is married to David Spina and they have four children. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Mars, Incorporated}} {{Wealthiest people in the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mars, Victoria B.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Yale
